title: 115_hr5270
content: The Act titled "Electricity Reliability and Fuel Security Act" provides a Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units under section 45T of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units under section 45T of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows taxpayers who own or lease such units to claim a credit equal to 30% of qualified expenses paid or incurred in a taxable year, or $13 multiplied by the unit's nameplate capacity rating in kilowatts, whichever is lesser. Qualified expenses refer to amounts paid for the operation of the unit. A coal-powered electric generation unit is defined as an electric generation unit that uses coal to produce at least 75% of the electricity generated. The Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units allows taxpayers to claim a credit for qualified expenses paid for the operation of such units. Qualified expenses exclude amounts paid for coal. Public entities can transfer the credit to eligible project partners. The Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units allows public entities to transfer the credit to eligible project partners. A qualified public entity includes government entities, mutual electric companies, and not-for-profit electric utilities that received a loan under the Rural Electrification Act. The Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units allows public entities to transfer the credit to eligible project partners involved in operating, maintaining, repairing, providing coal, financing, or leasing such units. Special rules apply to partnerships receiving the credit under subsection (a). Special rules apply to partnerships receiving the Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units. A qualified public entity is treated as the taxpayer for their share of the credit, and any partner of the partnership is considered an eligible project partner. The credit must be taken into account in the first taxable year if an election is made. The Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units allows eligible project partners to take the credit in the first taxable year ending with or after the qualified public entity's taxable year. Any benefit from this credit is not considered a private business use. The basis of the property is reduced by the amount of the credit allowed. This section applies to taxable years. The Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units allows eligible project partners to take the credit in the first taxable year ending with or after the qualified public entity's taxable year. The basis of the property is reduced by the amount of the credit allowed. This section applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2017, and ending before January 1, 2023. The Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units, under Sec. 45T, allows eligible project partners to take the credit in the first taxable year ending with or after the qualified public entity's taxable year. This section applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2017, and ending before January 1, 2023.
